bibl.title: Report to the Surgeon General, by James Carroll, August 18, 1906

div1.p: Carroll gives a detailed report about his involvement with the yellow fever project in Cuba and the necessity of having human volunteers. He also provides a listing of his publications. Included are notes by Truby. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
August 18, 1906.
To the
Surgeon General, U. S. Army.
Sir:-
div1.p:
In accordance with the desire of the Surgeon General,
expressed in letter of August 17, 1906, I have the honor to submit
the following statement:

In July, 1897, I was assigned with Major Reed to the work
of studying and reporting upon Sternberg's Bacillus X, and in Sept-
ember we were given a culture of Sanarelli's Bacillus icteroides which
he had reported to be the cause of yellow fever. At this time I was
on duty at the Army Medical School, assisting Major Reed. I held the
grade of Hospital Steward, was a graduate in medicine and had spent
about five years in bacteriological and pathological work exclusively
after having taken special post graduate courses in those subjects at
the Johns Hopkins.

Our first publication was A Preliminary Note (see enclosure
A, from The Medical News, New York, April 20, 1899) in which the striking
resemblances between Bacillus icteroides of Sanarelli and the Bog Cholera
bacillus were brought out. This called forth contradiction from Prof.
Sanarelli (Medical News, N. Y., August 12, 1899), to which a reply was
made after additional work confirming our first opinion (see enclosure
B, A Reply to Dr. G. Sanarelli, Medical News, N. Y., Sept. 9, 1899.).
-- 2 --
The work was continued, with many interruptions incident to the
Spanish American War, and the final and decisive report was com-
pleted in February, 1900, and published in the Journal of Experi-
mental Medicine in December of that year. (Copy marked enclosure C).
In the mean time the claims of Sanarelli for Bacillus icteroides as
the specific cause of yellow fever were sustained by several inves-
tigators, among the most important of whom were Drs. Wasdin and Ged-
dings of the Marine Hospital Service, who, in an elaborate and sensa-
tional report of almost 100 pages, pronounced B. icteroides the cause
of yellow fever and claimed to be able to infect dogs, monkeys, rabbits,
mice and other animals with yellow fever by inoculations with it.

Such was the status of the question when, in May, 1900, on the
recommendation of Surgeon General Sternberg, an order was issued con-
vening a board of Army Medical Officers on the Island of Cuba for the
investigation of yellow fever, which was at that time epidemic in
Havana. Major Reed and the undersigned sailed from the United States,
reaching Havana June 25, 1900, and the board, which consisted of Major
Walter Reed, Surgeon, Drs. James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear and Aristides
Agramonte, was convened on the following day in obedience to Par. 34,
S. O. 22, A. G. O., May 24, 1900. Work was begun immediately and
after a careful study of 18 cases of yellow fever with failure to dis-
cover a single specimen of Bacillus icteroides the result was regarded
as conclusive evidence that B. icteroides was not the cause of yellow
fever.

Early in the month of August it was decided to test the mosquito
theory advanced by Dr. Finlay, and since man is the only animal known
to suffer from yellow fever, there was no alternative but to make the
tests upon human beings. The question arose of the tremendous respons-
ibility of such an undertaking which could only be justified by the
enormous saving of life that would follow the establishment of the theory,
even should one or several lives be sacrificed in the course of the work.
The best atonement we could offer for endangering the lives of others was
to take the same chances ourselves, and it was agreed by Dr. Reed, Dr.
Lazear and myself that experiments should be undertaken and that we would
all be bitten by contaminated mosquitoes. Dr. Agramonte was kept in en-
tire ignorance of this part of the work by direction of Major Reed, as I
have written evidence to show, until after the first set of experiments
was completed and the report of them compiled for publication. Dr. Reed
left for the United States about August fourth2d, 1900, and the experiments
were begun by Dr. Lazear, the only member of the board who had had any
previous experience with mosquitoes. It was my part to continue the
bacteriological investigations as before. After nine unsuccessful at-
tempts to inoculate persons, including himself and one other medical of-
ficer, Acting Assistant Surgeon Pinto, Dr. Lazear succeeded in infecting
me with a single mosquito applied JulyAugust 27th, 1900, and upon the day that
I was taken sick, JulyAugust 31st, he applied the same insect, with others, to
a soldier, who after six days was down with yellow fever. On Sept. 13th
Dr. Lazear himself was bitten by a stray mosquito in Las Animas Hospital;
AET
- 4 --
he sickened Sept. 18th and died Sept. 25th, 1900, a martyr to the cause.
Major Reed returned Oct. 1st 4, 1900, wrote the report and presented it
at Indianapolis Oct. 22-26, 1900. (See The Etiology of Yellow Fever, A
Preliminary Note, Proceedings of The American Public Health Association,
meeting held in October 1900, copy marked D enclosed). I left Cuba for
the United States about October 11th, 1900, on sick leave for one month,
to recuperate, and returning about Nov. 11th took charge of the infected
mosquitoes used in subsequent experiments, participating in the general
work and devoting special attention to the microscopic study of the blood
of cases of yellow fever. The results obtained at Havana up to March
1st, 1901, were reported in the Journal of the American Medical Associa-
tion, Feb. 16, 1901 (enclosure E) and in American Medicine July 6, 1901
enclosure F). Dr. Agramonte was relieved from the board early in the
summer of 1901.

In the beginning of August, 1901, the undersigned returned
to Cuba, under orders, alone, for the purpose of making certain experi-
ments bearing upon the causative agent of yellow fever. Dr. John
Guiteras, of Havana, had made unsuccessful attempts at inoculation
throughout the summer and his first case was taken sick on the day
of my arrival. This was followed by six other experimental cases,
among them Miss Maas, an American woman nurse, who, with two others
of the seven, died. Dr. Guiteras declined to permit me to use his
cases for my work, and after the conclusion of his work I obtained
some of his infected mosquitoes through the courtesy of Col. Havard,
Chief Surgeon, and proceeded to inoculate. The experiments were
-- 5 --
brought to a successful conclusion after the inoculation of six per-
sons with yellow fever, all of whom recovered. In this work it was
shown for the first time that the specific cause of yellow fever was
sufficiently minute to pass through a new Barkefeld filter capable of
holding back the smallest of the ordinary known bacteria, and it was
further shown, for the first time, that the infectious power of yellow
fever blood was completely destroyed by a temperature of 55°C. (See
enclosure G, from American Medicine, Feb. 22, 1902.). These results,
as well as the other findings of the board, were all confirmed in the
following year by Messrs. Marchoux, Salimbeni and Simond, a commission
from the Pasteur Institute at Paris, who were working in Brazil. The
accompanying photograph of a cartoon, (Enclosure J) with Dr. Ross as the central figure,
taken from a daily paper, shows the state of public feeling in Havana
after the death of Dr. Guiteras' cases and before my first case was in-
oculated. It is worthy of note that this work was begun by me against
the protests of Dr. John Guiteras and Dr. Charles Finlay of Havana, and
of Dr. Ross, U. S. Navy, retired, then Director of Las Animas Hospital,
where I was quartered. I was convinced that with selected individuals,
properly treated, the work could be done with comparative safety. I wish
to make acknowledgment here of the strong and cordial support accorded
me by Col. Valery Havard, the Chief Surgeon, and without which the re-
sults could not have been accomplished.

Through the courtesy of Dr. Gorgas I enjoyed the privilege
on this occasion of making a post mortem examination of the first fatal
-- 6 --
case of Dr. Guiteras' series, and was thus able to show that the
lesions present in the experimental cases were identical with those
found in naturally infected cases of yellow fever.

In March, 1903, there was issued from the Yellow Fever In-
stitute of the U. S. Public Health and Marine Hospital Service the
report of a commission of medical officers entitled Working Party
No. 1, who described a protozoanparasite found in infected yellow
fever mosquitoes and which they regarded as of importance in connec-
tion with the disease (see page 31 of the report). In October of
the same year the undersigned reported before the meeting of the
American Public Health Association at Washington, D. C., that the
supposed protozoan parasites were yeast cells derived from the bananas
upon which they had been fed and proved it by demonstrating these bodies
in a number of mosquitoes by feeding to them pure cultures of yeast
isolated from bananas. (See enclosure H and enclosure M.) These results were gracefully and frankly
acknowledged by Dr. M. J. Rosenan, of the same service, in 1904. (See
page 1 of Bulletin No. 14 of the Yellow Fever Institute, the report
of Working Party No. 2, U. S. Public Health and Marine Hospital Service,
Washington, May 1904, enclosure I.).

The following publications on the subject of yellow fever have
been written by me apart from the conjoint publications of the Army
Board, viz:-

1. The Treatment of Yellow Fever, Journal of the American
Medical Association, July 19, 1902, enclosure K.
2. The Transmission of Yellow Fever, - ibid May 23, 1903, encl. L.

3. The Etiology of Yellow Fever, an addendum, - ibid November 28,
1903, enclosure M.

4. Yellow Fever, A Popular Lecture, American Medicine, June 3,
1905, enclosure N.

5. Lessons to be Learned from the Present Outbreak of Yellow Fever.
Journal of The American Medical Association, Oct. 7, 1905.
enclosure O.

6. Without Mosquitoes there can be no Yellow Fever. American
Medicine, March 17, 1906. Enclosure P.

7. Article on Yellow Fever. Mense's Handbuch der Tropenkrankheiten,
Vol. II, Leipzig, 1905.

8. Article on Yellow Fever. System of Medicine, Wm. Osler, Not yet
published.

I may be pardoned if I refer with pride to the following com-
ments of eminent professional men:-

President's address before the American Public Health Association
at New Orleans, La., 1902. Proceedings Amer. Pub. Health Ass'n., Vol. XXVIII,
Columbus, Ohio, 1903, pages 2 and 3.

President's address before the same association in 1905. See Pro-
ceedings of the American Public Health Association at the meeting at Havana,
Vol. XXX, 1905, page 1.

Report of Proceedings of the National Legislative Council of the
American Medical Association at the meeting held in Washington January
9-11, 1906. Journal of the American Medical Association, Jan. 20, 1906,
page 216, copy enclosed marked enclosure Q.

Attention is respectfully invited to my description in the first
paragraph on page 18 of the paper on The Treatment of Yellow Fever, in
-- 8 --
which I described a paroxysm suffered during the course of my
attack of yellow fever, and which I now believe to have been one
of acute cardiac dilatation. As a matter of fact I am now hampered
by a pronounced mitral regurgitation, on account of which I have been
cautioned by several physicians, including Dr. Thayer of Baltimore,
to go slow and be careful.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully,
Your obedient servant, James Carroll 1st Lieut. & Asst. Surgeon, U. S. Army.
Curator, Army Medical Museum.
(17 enclosures.)
